case_name: Alembic Chemical Works Co. Ltd. v. Its Workmen

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 475 of 1960 filed by Alembic Chemical Works Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 475 of 1960. Appeal by special leave from the Award dated

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated March 31, 1960 of the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated March 31, 1960, of the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay, in Reference  I. T.  No. 227 of 1959.

facts.text: Reference I. T. No. 227 of 1959 before Industrial Tribunal, Bombay

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated March 31, 1960, of the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay, in Reference  I. T.  No. 227 of 1959. MC.

facts.text: Industrial dispute between appellant Alembic Chemical Works Co. Ltd. and respondents its workmen regarding leave demand

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave arises from an industrial dispute between the appellant, the Alembic Chemical Works Co. Ltd., and the respondents, its workmen. The said dispute related to a single demand made by the respondents with regard to leave.

facts.text: Respondents demand consisted of three parts regarding privilege leave, sick leave, and proportional leave

anchor.surface_text: This demand companysisted of three parts,  a  one months privilege leave with full salary and dearness allowance on companypletion of eleven months service in a year with a right to accumulate upto six months,  b  one months sick leave with full salary and dearness allowance for each year of service with right to accumulate for the entire period of service, and  c  every workman should be entitled to take leave in proportion to the number of days he is in service of the companypany at the time of his application for the same.

facts.text: Dispute referred by Government of Bombay for adjudication before Industrial Tribunal under s. 10(1)(d) of Industrial Disputes Act 1947

anchor.surface_text: This dispute was referred by the Government of Bombay for adjudication before the Industrial Tribunal under s. 10 1  d  of the Industrial Disputes Act XIV of 1947.

facts.text: Tribunal awarded privilege leave: up to 3 completed years 16 days per year; up to 9 years 22 days per year; thereafter one month for every 11 months; accumulation up to three years

anchor.surface_text: In regard to privilege leave the Tribunal has ordered that leave should be granted to the staff members companyered by the reference as follows Privilege leave upto 3 16 days as at present companypleted years of service per year. Up to 9 companypleted years 22 days per year. And thereafter One month for every 11 months of service. The award allows accumulation of privilege leave upto three years.

facts.text: Tribunal awarded 15 days sick leave per year with full pay and dearness allowance, accumulation up to 45 days; no medical certificate demanded for sick leave of three days or less

anchor.surface_text: As regards sick leave, the Tribunal has ordered that the appellant should give its staff companyered by the present award 15 days sick leave in a year with full pay and dearness allowance with a right to accumulate upto 45 days. It has also directed that numbermedical certificate should be demanded if sick leave for three days or less is asked for.

facts.text: Appellant contended before Tribunal against propriety and reasonableness of demands and practices in comparable concerns

anchor.surface_text: Before the Tribunal the main companytention raised by the appellant was in regard to the propriety and reasonableness of the demand and in regard to the practice prevailing in companyparable companycerns.

facts.text: Award provisions for privilege leave attacked before Supreme Court on ground Tribunal lacked jurisdiction due to s.79 Factories Act 1948

anchor.surface_text: Before this Court, however, the provision made by the award in regard to privilege leave has been attacked mainly on the ground that the Tribunal had numberjurisdiction to make such an award having regard to the provisions of s. 79 of the Factories Act, 1948  63 of 1948   hereafter called the Act .

facts.text: Respondents are governed by provisions of Factories Act 1948

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the respondents are governed by the pro- visions of the Act.

facts.text: s.79 point not raised before Tribunal but permitted in Supreme Court as point of law on admitted facts

anchor.surface_text: This point was number raised before the Tribunal, but since it is a point of law which arises on admitted facts we have permitted the learned Attorney- General to argue it before us.

facts.text: Factories Act first enacted in 1934 as Act 25 of 1934, amended from time to time

anchor.surface_text: The Act was first enacted in 1934 as Act 25 of 1934. Since then it has been amended from time to time.

facts.text: Award purports to provide privilege leave in excess of annual leave under s.79 Factories Act

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that the award purports to make provisions for privilege leave in excess of the annual leave sanctioned by s. 79.

facts.text: Distinction made between clerical staff covered by present reference and operatives covered by earlier awards

anchor.surface_text: Then it is urged that the provision made by the award for privilege leave introduces discrimination between the clerical staff companyered by the present reference and operatives companyered by the earlier awards made by the same Tribunal.

facts.text: Operatives made similar claim for privilege leave before same Tribunal which was rejected

anchor.surface_text: We were told that operatives had made a similar claim for privilege leave before the same Tribunal, and the said claim had been rejected.

facts.text: Appellant's standing orders make different provisions for operatives and clerical staff

anchor.surface_text: It is number seriously disputed that a distinction has generally been made between operatives who do manual work and clerical and other staff in fact the appellants standing orders themselves make different relevant provisions for the two categories of its employees.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J. on December 15, 1960

anchor.surface_text: 1960. December 15. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-This appeal by special leave arises from an industrial dispute between the appellant, the Alembic Chemical Works Co. Ltd., and the respondents, its workmen.

facts.text: s.79(1) Factories Act provides annual leave with wages: 1 day/20 days work for adults, 1/15 for children, after 240 days work

anchor.surface_text: Section 79 1  occurs in Chapter VIII which deals with annual leave with wages. It provides thus 79.  1 . Every worker who has worked for a period of 240 days or more in a factory during a calendar year shall be allowed during the subsequent calendar year, leave with wages for a number of days calculated at the rate of- if an adult, one day for every twenty days of work performed by him during the previous calendar year if a child, one day for every fifteen days of work performed by him during the previous calendar year.

facts.text: Tribunal considered contentions, awards and agreements in comparable concerns before making award

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal companysidered the companytentions raised by the appellant against the respondents demands, took into account awards or agreements between employers and their employees in companyparable companycerns and made its award.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld Tribunal's award on privilege leave against s.79 challenge

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the challenge to the validity of the award based on the assumption that s. 79 1  provides for standardised award of annual leave with wages fails.

facts.text: Distinction between operatives and clerical staff made in comparable concerns and awards

anchor.surface_text: It is also number disputed that in practice such distinction is made by companyparable companycerns, and awards based on the same distinction are generally made in respect of the two separate categories of employees.
This appeal by special leave arises from an industrial dispute between the appellant, the Alembic Chemical Works Co. Ltd., and the respondents, its workmen.
out for interference in an appeal under Art. 136.

whether making liberal provisions for privilege leave and sick leave are really opposed to the modern trend in industrial thought

arguments.claim: Tribunal lacked jurisdiction to award privilege leave in excess of s.79 Factories Act because s.79 makes exhaustive, self-contained provisions standardizing annual leave with wages as maximum, no additions by employer voluntarily or by Tribunal award; s.79 is complete code for leave

anchor.surface_text: Before this Court, however, the provision made by the award in regard to privilege leave has been attacked mainly on the ground that the Tribunal had no jurisdiction to make such an award having regard to the provisions of s. 79 of the Factories Act, 1948 (63 of 1948) hereafter called the Act .

arguments.claim: Before Tribunal, demands for leave improper/unreasonable compared to practices in comparable concerns

arguments.claim: s.79(1) prima facie provides for minimum leave with wages, not maximum

anchor.surface_text: when s. 79(1) provides that every worker shall be allowed leave as therein prescribed, the provision prima facie sounds like a provision for the minimum rather than for the maximum leave which may be awarded to the worker.

arguments.claim: Even if ambiguous, prefer construction furthering Act's policy/beneficial to employees (beneficent construction for welfare legislation)

anchor.surface_text: Section 84 provides that where the State Government is satisfied that the leave rules applicable to workers in a factory provide benefits which in its opinion are not less favourable than those for which Chapter VIII makes provision

arguments.claim: Legislative history/amendments show progressive liberalization of leave provisions

anchor.surface_text: The history of the amendments made in the relevant provisions of the Act also indicates that the Act has been gradually making more liberal provisions in the interest of workmen to whom it applies.

arguments.claim: Distinction between clerical staff and operatives justified; common in practice, standing orders, comparables, awards; no discrimination

anchor.surface_text: It is not seriously disputed that a distinction has generally been made between operatives who do manual work and clerical and other staff in fact the appellants standing orders themselves make different relevant provisions

arguments.claim: Under Art.136, reluctant to interfere with Tribunal award unless unsustainable on reasonable ground or violent departure from practice/trend

anchor.surface_text: unless it appears that the impugned provisions cannot be sustained on any reasonable ground or that they mark a violent departure from the prevailing practice or trend, we would be reluctant to interfere with the decision of the Tribunal.

arguments.claim: Industrial adjudication for social justice must balance workmen welfare with national economy/production needs

holdings.text: The Industrial Tribunal has jurisdiction to award privilege leave in excess of the annual leave with wages provided under s.79 of the Factories Act, 1948, as s.79(1) does not standardize annual leave as a maximum but provides for the minimum.

anchor.surface_text: Can the Industrial Tribunal direct the appellant to provide such additional privilege leave to its employees? in other words, does s. 79 purport to standardise annual leave with wages so that no departure from the said standard is permissible either way? The appellants contention is that except for pre-existing awards,

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.79(1) prima facie prescribes minimum leave due to language used; ss.78(1) and 84 expressly allow exceptions including future awards, agreements providing longer leave; beneficent construction for welfare legislation; legislative history shows progressive liberalization.

holdings.text: s.78(1) of the Factories Act protects rights under existing and future laws, awards, agreements or contracts of service providing longer annual leave than s.79.

anchor.surface_text: Section 78 1  provides that the provisions of Chapter VIII shall not operate to the prejudice of any right to which a worker may be entitled under any other law, or under the terms of any award, agreement or contract of service. There is a proviso to this sub-section which lays down that when such award,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading not limited to pre-existing arrangements; otherwise would restrict future legislation or awards inconsistent with welfare policy and standardisation concept.

holdings.text: s.84 of the Factories Act allows exemption for factories providing better leave benefits, including future ones, confirming s.79 not as maximum.

anchor.surface_text: Section 84 provides that where the State Government is satisfied that the leave rules applicable to workers in a factory provide benefits which in its opinion are not less favourable than those for which Chapter VIII makes provision it may by written order exempt the factory

holdings.reasoning_summary: Power contemplates totality of benefits better than Chapter VIII, applicable to future improvements; rejecting appellant's construction avoids illogical consequences.

holdings.text: The award's provision for privilege leave does not discriminate between clerical staff and operatives as the distinction is justifiable and commonly made.

anchor.surface_text: Then it is urged that the provision made by the award for privilege leave introduces discrimination between the clerical staff covered by the present reference and operatives covered by the earlier awards made by the same Tribunal. We were told that operatives had made a similar claim for privilege leave before the same Tribunal,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction between manual operatives and clerical staff standard in standing orders, comparable concerns, and awards; justifiable difference, no vice of discrimination.

holdings.text: In appeals under Art.136 against industrial awards, the Supreme Court is reluctant to interfere unless provisions cannot be sustained on reasonable ground or mark violent departure from prevailing practice or trend.

anchor.surface_text: unless it appears that the impugned provisions cannot be sustained on any reasonable ground or that they mark a violent departure from the prevailing practice or trend, we would be reluctant to interfere with the decision of the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deference to Tribunal's expertise in considering comparables and trends; applied here as award sustainable.

holdings.text: The Tribunal's liberal provisions for privilege leave and sick leave are not opposed to modern industrial trends and warrant no interference.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Balances social justice with economy; Tribunal considered relevant factors and comparables; no unsustainable grounds or violent departure justifying Art.136 interference.

outcome.relief_summary: No case made out for interference with the Industrial Tribunal's award granting privilege leave and sick leave
